practiceScenarios.title: Opening Statement
practiceScenarios.context: Debate on social media regulation. You support requiring platforms to be more transparent about algorithmic amplification.
practiceScenarios.sampleResponse: Today we're not debating whether social media has changed public discourse—we know it has. We're debating whether citizens have a right to understand how. When you open a news app, an algorithm decides what you see. That algorithm is designed not to inform but to engage—and outrage engages. The result: we're each presented with a different reality, optimized not for truth but for clicks. This isn't just a commercial issue; it's a democratic one. Voters can't make informed decisions when their information is shaped by systems they don't understand and can't see. Our proposal is modest: require platforms to disclose the basic principles by which content is ranked and amplified. Not their proprietary code—just enough for citizens to understand why they're seeing what they're seeing. Our opponents will say this threatens innovation. But democracy shouldn't be sacrificed for innovation we don't understand. Transparency isn't censorship; it's the foundation of accountability.

practiceScenarios.title: Rebuttal
practiceScenarios.context: Your opponent argued that media literacy education is sufficient without platform regulation.
practiceScenarios.sampleResponse: My opponent puts the entire burden on individual users to navigate a system designed by some of the world's most sophisticated engineers to exploit human psychology. Think about that. They're saying that a teenager should be expected to out-think algorithms refined by billions in investment to capture attention. Media literacy helps—we don't dispute that—but it's a complement to structural solutions, not a substitute. Consider: we require nutritional labels on food. We don't say, 'Just educate people about nutrition and let companies hide ingredients.' The information asymmetry is too great. The same logic applies here. And crucially, my opponent's approach leaves the business model untouched. As long as platforms profit from engagement regardless of accuracy, they have no incentive to change. Our approach aligns incentives with outcomes. Transparency creates accountability; education alone cannot.
